wikitext.*:
'''''lókë''''' is a noun meaning "[[Snakes|snake]], [[Serpents|serpent]]" in [[Quenya]].<ref>{{S|Appendix}}, entry ''lok-'' (glossed as ''(h)lókë'')</ref>

The ([[Qenya]]) form ''lóke (-ī)'' ("dragon") also appears.<ref name=Ety370>{{LR|Etymologies}}, p. 370</ref> In earlier manuscripts appear the forms ''lókë'' ("drake")<ref>{{LT2|Appendix}}, p. 340 (entry '''Foalókë''')</ref> and ''lōke'' ("dragon").<ref>{{PE|11}}, p. 74 (entry '''ulug''')</ref>

It has been suggested that the spelling according to the Quenya style of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' would be ''lócë'', meaning "dragon, snake, serpent, drake".<ref>[[Helge Fauskanger]], ''Quettaparma Quenyallo'' (accessed 9 December 2010)</ref>

==Etymology==
It is derived from the [[Elvish]] [[Sundocarme|root]] [[LOK]].<ref name=Ety370/><ref>{{PE|17}}, p. 160</ref>
==Examples==
*[[Urulóki]]
*''[[Glaurung#Other versions of the legendarium|Foalókë]]''
